course.subject: LANG
course.name: Science Communication in English (Life Science)
course.description: The course focuses on developing students' ability to communicate life science knowledge to the general public through effective writing and speaking skills. In writing, students learn the specific skills to produce genres of both expository and persuasive nature, and reflect on how to explain life science concepts in an accessible manner without losing the scientific complexity. In speaking, students learn how to communicate life science notions and implications to nonexpert audiences using short videos and oral presentations with appropriate rhetorical and stylistic devices. For BCB, BISC and BIOT students only.
course.prerequisites: (For DDP only) CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1003 (prior to 2022-23); (For all others) LANG 2010

reviews.comment_content: Story-telling techniques, how to write op-ed articles, and presentation skills about Life Science.

reviews.comment_workload:
Quite high.

SA1: A video of yourself talking about the impact of a Life Science topic using story-telling between 2.5 to 3.5 minutes.

SA2: A TED-style talk to persuade the audience of your opinion on a controversial life science issue between 8 to 10 minutes.

You have to present in-class and no note cards allowed. Writing a 8 minutes-worth of script is already tiring, not to mention that you have to recite the whole thing to be fluent during the presentation. It's also easy to make a few slips or forget some of the scripts, which is my case. Do try not to panic and recover as soon as possible.

WA: An op-ed article between 1000-1200 words on the topic you chose for SA2. So pick your topic carefully, otherwise you may have a hard time brainstorming what to write.

In-class participation: The checkpoint tasks are just some short discussions, peer evaluations, and writing a few sentences on Canvas's discussion board.

reviews.author: Colton
reviews.comment_content:
Most weeks students will attend three hours of class and will be expected to complete up to three hours of out-of-class work per week. The course focuses on two overarching themes:
Science communication and story-telling
You will gain an understanding of the importance of science communication and the role of story-telling therein, developing the skills to effectively analyse popular science articles and presentations aimed at the general public, as well as to use appropriate strategies to make your own science communication – writing and speaking – accessible and interesting to lay audiences.
Communicating controversy in Life Science
You will gain an understanding of public attitudes to and controversies in Life Science and how such controversies are presented in speech and in writing, developing the skills to critically read and write about – as well as present – scientific controversies in an accessible and interesting way to lay audiences.
reviews.comment_teaching: SHEN teaches very patient. She is a really nice teacher, and she would ask different questions to allow us to have clear pictures on the story telling techniques and also the reference text. There are also many discussions during lessons.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite good. Although I am not doing really well in my assignment, she gives me quite good grade, which above 5 in all columns. So i think the grading is quite good. However the final grade is not released, so it is not sure yet.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload of this course is quite high. For SHEN, she needs us to do different practice like presenting ppt, self introduction clips before the real assignment. But It is really helpful. There will be total 4 assignment. For 2 in speaking and 2 in writing. So the workload os quite high.

reviews.author: schuinmg
reviews.title: Good grade, nice teaching
reviews.comment_content:
LANG 3024 – Science Communication in English (Life Science) – is a three-credit course offered to third-year students in Life Science. Most weeks students will attend three hours of class and will be expected to complete up to three hours of out-of-class work per week. The course focuses on two overarching themes:

1.Science communication and story-telling
You will gain an understanding of the importance of science communication and the role of story-telling therein, developing the skills to effectively analyse popular science articles and presentations aimed at the general public, as well as to use appropriate strategies to make your own science communication – writing and speaking – accessible and interesting to lay audiences.
2.Communicating controversy in Life Science
You will gain an understanding of public attitudes to and controversies in Life Science and how such controversies are presented in speech and in writing, developing the skills to critically read and write about – as well as present – scientific controversies in an accessible and interesting way to lay audiences.


Task Type
Inspiring interest: the impact of life science Spoken 20%
Telling the story of the development of a life science idea Written 20%
TED-style talk on a life science controversy Spoken 25%
Op-ed article on a life science controversy Written 25%
Participation: in-class and out-of-class work Both 10%
